It has similar mesmerizing atmosphere of strange empty rooms, simple geometrical shapes and ambient music. This world is somewhat between ancient tomb and alien spaceship, but sometimes you'll find something weirdly realistic.

It is gloomy and meditative but in the end you getting deep and pleasant experience.

There are no enemies
There are no upgrades
There is no crosshair
There is no quest
There is nothing to guide you but the map in the pause screen

The atmosphere created is 10/10, very sureal and unsettling at times. Like other top reviews say, this reminds me of a weird M.C. Esther-esque Gone Home/Myst/Antichamber. The exploration is unforced, the puzzles are challenging and they require thought. The player instantly understands what a puzzle is about when they start trying to solve it. The game has a certain charm about it that I love.

Also the default controls are ♥♥♥♥, make sure the sensitivity is waaaaay down. Even if it is, expect major frame rate drops during puzzle rooms and ESSPECIALLY in the Lighthouse Hub (the 2nd picture), It wasn't even over 30 fps at times in that room.

Incredible puzzle game. Minimalistic art style fits this wonderfully. Only issues are controls (you tend to have a lot of momentum so go slow on edges), puzzles (they vary widely on difficulty), and size (the game is really too big). Get this if you enjoy puzzle games or exploration games. It's tons of fun.

Kairo isn't your standard issue game; it's more of a playable piece of digital art really.

It is a world abstracted into basic geometric shapes, drenched in monotone hues, and brought with eerily alien music.  It doesn't contain the usual button mashing or killing stuff, but instead is about exploration and solving puzzles (nothing hard really).  It's fairly short, but will offer a unique experience you won't find anywhere else.

I have to write a review for this game while it's fresh in my mind.  Kairo is every bit as fun and eerie as you would want a 3D puzzle game to be.  Do yourself a favor and play this game alone and uninterrupted for a full immersive feel.  There are no verbal cues - as in you will never have another character speak to you, and you will never hear your own character talk.  There aren't any written cues or instructions beyond symbols you find (and of course the gentle hints in your menu screen, should you need them).  It's all about using the landscape and the machines and puzzles to your advantage - to a visual person like me, this was a wonderful experience.  Each different area in the game has its own color scheme and chosen background music and sounds from one of the game's tracks (the music is great for the game and ranges from Fairly soothing and enlightening"
date: to "I feel like someone just shoved ice down the back of my shirt").  In terms of graphics

The maker of this game knew what he was doing and while it's a little rough around the edges in some regards (I guess) the game is -solid- in the graphics department to me.  It feels like the great machines are actually working next to you.  That you're standing next to sources of great power

Lastly I want to talk about the storyline - There is a lump that forms in the pit of your stomach once you start realizing where this game is going and the gravity of what has already happened and the gravity of what you might actually be doing. reviewText: A strange but compelling experience. If Oculus Rift works on this game, it'll definitely be a very trippy ride! Worth checking out!

It's hard to decide whether to give this game a recommendation or not. I liked it, but this game is absolutely not for everyone. Its very artsy, which will be a turnoff for some. There are environmental type puzzles to solve -- and sometimes it is not at all clear what to do. The graphics don't get any better than the screenshots.  The game has a science fiction vibe, but it's more of an atmospheric game; not a lot of plot as such.\n\nIf you like exploring, and like a sci-fi type atomosphere, and don't mind a game that is artistic rather than traditionally fun, you might enjoy the game. I did. But that was a long list of qualifiers.

Very fun atmospheric puzzle game, in the same vein as Myst.  Puzzles are abstract and often require a flash of insight, but never feel nonsensical.  Environments are monochromatic and bleak, but in a way that comes off as ominous instead of bland.  The backstory is told in only a few scattered pieces of scenery, and left to interpretation.\n\nThe main game can be reasonably completed without ever looking at a guide, but you'll have to in order to 100% (one of the puzzles gives each player only one part of the solution and is literally impossible to figure out alone).

Very cryptic game. You will feel like a fine craftsman trying to repair an immense mechanism of which you can't grasp the entire dimension and function, and yet, each part of it it's so beautiful in its minimalistic design.\n\nThe puzzles aren't hard to solve and it won't take you a lot of time to travel through the entire world. For that matter, someone will probably call this game more of a walking simulator"
date: but maybe in this case a "vision" simulator label could be appropriate."

Rewarding puzzle game. If you try it and you can't figure out what to do, just use your observation skills to get you started. It's as simple as that. Best played with something to write down things on ;)

Kairo is so awesome it's... well, awesome. It's immersive, enjoyable, and has a lot of meaning.

An intriguing first person puzzle and exploration game with unique architech. Sure there are a few annoying puzzles here and there, but the main thing about this game is exploration, which is what I love about this game.

Let me first say that if you are expecting Kairo to be something along the lines of Myst, Riven or, for that matter, any challenging puzzler, do not buy. The puzzles lack depth, complexity, and do not require deep thinking in order to discover the solution. They feel like an afterthought and I think the developer intentionally designed them so to make the experience in Kairo more fluid.

As you may have read, Kairo is a minimalist exploration game (though it's more of an abstract art gallery simulator). Meaning you can only walk, run, and jump. Your interaction with machines is restricted thus partially explaining the lack of depth in some of the puzzles. No in game button prompts. Nothing out of the Kairo's context distracts you, save the notification that informs you've solved a puzzle. It's all for the purpose of pulling you deep into Kairo's world full of abstract architecture and objects with strange behavior that apparently defies physics. The fine grain filter and errie soundtrack assist in attempting to build an absorbing atmosphere.

Except I felt a disconnect for some reason. None of the abstract architectures (nor the atmosphere) evoked any feelings. No texts located anywhere to provide some backstory. Perhaps (and I'm not sure) some story could be deciphered (or interpreted) but the game gave me no reason or motivation to invest the effort into it. Even during the conclusion when Kairo's purpose was hinted at, no tingle of emotion.

In my opinion, you can approach this game like you approach a strange dream right after waking up, either invest the energy to interpret it and derive personal meaning or instantly forget about all the vague disjointed images. If you're the former or if the idea of an abstract art gallery simulator sounds appealing, then maybe Kairo might be for you.

However, if you are looking for something with cohesion and a game that gradually unfolds a story with clarity (or a challenging puzzler as talked about in first paragraph) then I would defintely pass this one up.

Graphics:
I could not shake off the feeling that all those duplicated cubes with the exact same texture were not a bold artistic design, but rather a result of laziness. Overall it felt extremely cheap --- You could say that it's fitting since the game is really cheap. That last remark aside, I would have preferred a smaller, but more polished world.

Puzzles:
The puzzles are never really satisfying to solve. There are mostly button-pressing chores, that you find yourself solving for not particular reasons. After playing for a while, I just wanted to get done with them as quickly as possible, which I guess defeats the purpose of the game...

This game puts you into an existential crisis.


11/10 would cower into a corner and start crying again

Kairo isn't a game for everybody.  In fact, I wouldn't even say it was a game for most people.  It's the type of game that takes a lot of patience to enjoy.  You've got to really put yourself into the game, imagine that you're really in this place, seeing these things.  The atmosphere and mystery are everything, and if that isn't your bag then you won't find enough to enjoy here when it comes to pure gameplay.

There are indeed puzzles to be solved, but most of them are quite simple.  There are no controls beyond moving around and jumping, and there's no text or story to speak of beyond what you're observing of your environment.  As is to be expected with these types of games, a lot of it is open for interpretation, including the ending.  The graphics are solid, but quite simple and low-budget; most of the architecture is made up of blocks and flat planes.

If any of those things are deal-breakers, then don't even bother.  But if you're into the pure sense of discovery that games can offer then I can't possibly recommend it enough.  The term gets tossed around a lot, but it truly is more of an experience than a game.  You've got to like abstraction, simplicity, and rich atmosphere (thanks in large part to the excellent sound design).  You've got to be the type of person who gets a thrill from the simple act of booting up a game and not knowing exactly what to expect--of heading through a door and not having the foggiest idea of what you'll see.

There isn't much more to say about the game.  If it's not your cup of tea, nothing else here will be relevant to you.  If it is, then there's no need for me to explain what was great about it with more detail, because it's already obvious that you should play it.  I mean hey, it's five bucks, and as I type this it's on sale for one whole dollar.  Even if the story only lasts a few hours, that's a stupidly good deal for such an experience.

Pretty frustrated with the game at first, and I ended up marathoning it to 100% completion.  Took about 6 hours total, with breaks.  Puzzles are fun, albiet some of them are kinda frustrating.  I ended up just guessing on one of them to get it.\n\nVERY recommended, but keep in mind it's an adventure puzzle game before picking it up.  Well worth the money, imo.

reviewText:
I unfortunately got this game just days before it went on sale, but at full price it still felt like an amazing deal.  Imagine LSD: Dream Emulator but texturally subdued and transformed into a relatively linear puzzle game, with just a dash of the Assassin's Creed 2 glyph sequences for flavor.

The graphics and designs of the game are unimpressive, but not uninentionally so.  The minimalism of both the visuals and the music create a complexly desolate atmosphere, and, like LSD, the emptiness of the world never comes off as a result of laziness but of tasteful restraint.  It's easy to fill a puzzle game with distracting elements that intrude on the experience as a whole, but it's refreshing to see one that makes an enjoyable experience using only movement controls and basic graphics.

In the vein of games like Fract OSC, Antichamber, The Devil's Tuning Fork, and Against the Wall, this is a game that does not hold the player's hand at any point and does not even provide any form of communication or instruction to the player until the ending, allowing for total uninterrupted exploration, and the game is intuitive enough to keep going at a steady pace regardless.  This makes sense in an internal way, as well, as the game is set in a long abandoned universe in which the player is a complete stranger.

The ending is a bit cheesy and the sequences that reveal the world's story are unoriginal at best.  I was also unimpressed by the various photographs and videos that attempted to connect Kairo to Earth, which appear incessantly throughout the game just incase the message wasn't received the first few times.  In a puzzle game that involves some amount of thought in order to progress, this felt patronizing and undermined the feeling that the game developer trusts the player to make the connections themselves.  The alien and deserted tone of the game was also diminished by this forced message, which left me wishing that the game had remained mysterious and totally detached from the real world like it initially appeared.  It seems as if the game was created first, but in the later stages of development the developer decided to tack a deeper story onto the game, conflicting with the original vision for the project.

Bland connotations aside, I didn't expect to spend nine hours in this game, and it says something about Kairo that I can spend a day backtracking through every area multiple times in order to unlock the achievements and the secret ending and still have fond memories of the experience (even if the secret ending was a massive disappointment).

Ultimately, I would recommend this game if you want something that has a poweful and moving atmosphere, but if you're just looking for a puzzle game then look elsewhere, as the puzzles here aren't as memorable as the overarching experience.

reviewText: I really wanted to like Kairo but there is too much wrong with it for me to enjoy. The game doesn't make it clear when it saves and it doesn't give you the option to save whenever you want. This resulted in me completing major puzzles of the game and then leaving only to come back days later and realize that twenty minutes of work was gone. The player also moves to slow for some of the larger room puzzles which means correcting mistakes is a pain and bother. The only thing I really liked about the game was the lack of a HUD although at times this meant that I had no idea what to do since there was never any instructions. Honestly, a quick save feature would have made me love this game or at the very least an icon that shows when the game is saving but with neither of those things, I would highly recommend you avoid this game.

reviewText:
If you have ever went on a walk, in an empty gymnasium with your eyes closed, you probably would find Kairo boring in comparison. In Kairo you get to do a lot of walking. I think. Actually I have no idea what this game actually IS.... When I am playing it, I feel as though I'm stuck in Half Life's tram car, able to look around, move a little, but nothing actually happens.
Actually that's a bit generous. It's more like waiting for your girlfriend to come downstairs for your date - you can walk around, check out the books on her book shelf, look at the dirt on the floor... all with an anticipation that she would be coming down stairs ANY minute,., She never does - and THAT's Kairo's entire gameplay model.
Did I like it? I can't say, I never actually DID anything. Oh sure, doors opened, things clicked, but unless I'm missing the point, the entire purpose of this game is to show how nicely you can make big ugly square blocks look sometimes.
I'd like to see what the developer actually intended, some day.

reviewText:
I Don't Get It, And I Don't Have a Clue About Whats Going On
Kairo is a isolated world in a unknown mysterious world, where you have to figure out puzzles that most of them make absolutely no sense at all You must try them countless times before u can solve them (Most likely by guessing).

The sense of being totally alone, and the big and small places, fit quite well with the game atmosphere,  it gives you a good experience, some parts are a bit creepy tho.

After beating the game, I still have no idea what just happened, and Its just amazing that way.

8/10. It was a great experience.

I think there's a Facebook User spying on me....

Great break from all the regular commercial gameplay! Chill, explore, discover new areas and puzzles while flowing in the realm of Kairo. I randomly stumbled upon this game and I loved every minute playing it and greatly recommend it if you're looking to try a different kind of puzzle game!

reviewText: As a puzzle-lover, I was really looking forward to this game since so many reviews compare it to other games I rather enjoyed, such as Anti-Chamber. However, I only got an hour into this game and was completely bored by it.\n\nThe graphics look like they were made in the mid-90s; things like the original Unreal had higher poly counts than this does, and more graphical cohesion. Just about everything is done with blocks and the textures, in-as-much as they are even used, seem to be just tossed on to objects as almost an after-thought. Even water" is just a bunch of disconnected rectangles. Rooms have seemingly random color selections

reviewText: Alltogether Kairo isn't seriously a real game. It's more like a playable art project. And it supports as one of the first demos OR, but what doesn't count anymore (FB ♥♥♥♥ed that up). Even without OR you become sick of this weird spinning graphics in fisheye optic. It seems they used somekind of Doom1 engine to render all the pseudo 3D objects. Minecraft has more details than this. The psychadelic colors in each room doesn't make it better. You begin this game and have no plan what to do. No instructions, no hints. Just get lost in the labrinth of colored rooms and corridors. The hidden multimedia clips are creepy also the threaten atmosphere. But why asking of any sense? Art is as better as more senseless it is. Don't buy it directly. If it's in a bundle added, it's OK.

reviewText:
What am I even doing?

Kairo is a very beautiful and ambient puzzle game with zero help and is the complete opposite of linear. It had puzzles and walking parts that have no connection and will leave you completely lost 95% of the way, some people may like that but it was a massive turn off for me. I used a guide for most of the game just so I could get it finished and write this review.

My girlfriend tried it so I could make sure it wasent just me not knowing what I was doing, shes very puzzle smart and gets these kinda things really easily, but she became frustrated at the lack of help you are given. Most of the puzzles have no logical conclusion and will just make you guess forever until you figure it with just blind luck and perserverence.

What it does right is make a story and really get the feeling of mystery and uncertainty embeded into the entire experience.

With a guide it took me 3.5 hours to complete, without I would say if you didn't go insane already and forgot what time even is it will take 10+

I really wanted to recommend this game, I bought it on sale thinking it was going to be this amazing ambient adventure with clear colours and pretty shapes but I really can't, it just makes no sense.

It had promise and if it had just a little help to give you it would of been three times the game it is, but all I experienced was a mess of beautiful art.

Personal Rating: 2/5

reviewText:
When I saw the screenshots and such for Kairo I presumed that Kairo may not be the most visually appealing game but sometimes, while such games may not always put their best screenshots on display, they do usually have some redeeming charm. The various positive reviews and an endorsement from RPS also seemed to indicate that this was a diamond in the rough. However as it turned out, it is actually a mouldy chunk of food in the dust. How on earth this game achieved anywhere near a positive status on Steam I have no idea, but I suspect foul play. Allow me to explain why you need to avoid Kairo like the plague.

Plain textures can sometimes be compensated for by some impressively detailed architecture or environments which hold intrigue. Kairo simply does not have any of that. The environments look like they were made by someone experimenting with mapping and decided to package everything together to make it seem like a game. The designer has some strange idea that throwing tons of fog into every section of the game is a substitute for creating atmospheric lighting or using the environment itself to influence the players' state of mind. As such every part of the game I saw felt lifeless, unfinished and bland. I have honestly seen maps from the original Quake with more atmosphere, style and imagination.

The 'puzzles' are so dull that I literally gave up after playing the game for half an hour. They consist of running into invisible triggers or standing on trigger brushes to cause something to happen. One of the things the designer forgot to actually do is clearly indicate when a puzzle is solved and what the point of solving it was. In one area I found 4 platforms which turned on a bunch of particle effects on a rotating central disc. Visually quite interesting and clearly the puzzle was solved because all of the triggers stopped working, but it did not appear to have any effect upon the game. The lack of direction here is astounding as the designer chooses to leave you completely in the dark as to what you should be doing and gives no context or sense of progress to what you manage to figure out on your own. Someone needs to sit this person down with games like Myst, the Longest Journey, Master Reboot or even The Room so they can understand the difference between an enjoyable mystery and aimless activity.

Kairo is unpleasant to look at, boring to explore, devoid of any sense of achievement or purpose and ultimately one of the worst games I have had the misfortune to mistake for a worthwhile investment of money or time.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Take a 90's shooter, skip on plot, guns and enemies. What you're left with is a bunch of unengaging puzzles which are only worthy of changing the pace between other gameplay elements, of which there are none now. Such puzzles consist of stepping on floor buttons in the correct order, shown on a wall in front of you. Levels are extremely low-poly and have single featureless texture tiled over most surfaces. Monochromatic environments, while making up for an appealing screenshot gallery, can be really nauseating.

In order to have a minimalist aesthetic appeal Kairo strives for, it would have to do all those small things right, like making footstep sounds actually match your walking speed, or not having them at all. Instead, its one of those games where you feel like you're stuck crouching constantly so you hit the crouch button to untoggle it, but the camera drops even lower.

reviewText: In Kairo, you solve ancient MEH-chanical puzzles in a minimalistic, highly abstract, Minecraft-like blocky world with ambient background music.\n\nStylistically, the game is decent, despite the Stone-Age graphics, but the puzzles are mostly unoriginal and repetitive. Most of the time, you activate mechanical contraptions (move around blocks, balls, light up ancient symbols) to get the correct order / combination / angle etc. That kind of stuff. Too much of it, and not very well done either.

reviewText:
Very strange, very mysterious, but also incredibly beatiful.

There is no introduction, no talking, nobody to hold your hand.
There are no tools and no weapons.
There is nothing but your natural human ability to walk, jump, push things and think.
And yet you almost always know what to do.
The world is silently guiding you through its majesty and testing your lateral thinking as you go.

The charm of this game comes from the simplicity of the controls, the great design of the environment and the sheer amount of mystery flowing through every room.

reviewText:
An absolutely incredible game... i loved it all the way through <3

Kairo is quiet and surreal, has incredible timing and pace, and constantly tickles your curiosity in order to compell you forward from each puzzle to the next. When the game is strange and alien, it is fascinating, but when it begins to hint at things familiar it turns creepy. The plot is revealed without ever resorting to the use of writing or words; a story told entirely through shapes, colors, and meaningfull images.

I cant believe this is only five dollars. I'll be watching these devolopers in the future to see what they come out with next... I will remember this game for awhile :)

reviewText: I didn't like Kairo. It feels unfinished. And the blinding white sky and strange visual appearance kind of give me a headache. The game doesn't teach well at all, so you feel unsure of what you should be doing. It is not nearly linear enough, and has no sense of accomplishment. I purchased it because it looked so promising, but the game fails to deliver. I hate to write a negative review, but this game is just not well put together or polished. The levels don't have a consistent feel or visual style, the architecture is not believable, navigation is difficult and the player just needs a LOT more direction.\n\nIf the game was linear, taught skills incrementally, was more intuitive, rewarded the player, had save points, and was easier to navigate it could be a really fun game. But it doesn't quite do what a game should. It has a lot of potential, though, and it is too bad that it isn't more finished.

reviewText:
I don't normally play exploration games.  Kairo is probably the closest thing to immersion that I wanted from a puzzle/exploration game besides the Myst series.  The music is the most immersive aspect of Kairo. It will bring you into this world.

It should be noted that there is no spoken dialogue or text to read. You start off in this world and have to figure out where to go and what to do. The puzzles aren't terribly difficult. The hardest one for me so far only took 20 minutes to solve.

I'm still playing this pretty awesome game for 5 bucks but I can already say it's worth a buy!

The game itself is fine, but at this point in trying to get the last two achievements, I have played it for 10 hours. reviewText:
I don't think I've ever regretted spending $5.

I put a little under an hour and a half into this game before I made the decision to uninstall it.

Here is my reasoning.

I bought the game because some reviewers touted its similarity to Antichamber, a game that is very near and dear to my heart. The trailer for the game made it appear tantalizing and intriguing and, most of all, fun.

Unfortunately, it didn't take me twenty minutes to regret this small purchase.

Kairo has, I've found, missed the mark on one of the most fundamental gaming concepts; not just in video games, but in the entire realm of playing a game for fun. I call this carrot-and-stick". Other people call this other things. But essentially
date: in nearly every game you can think of
hoursPlayed: your objective
helpfulPercent: what keeps you from your objective. I could cite endless games
votesHelpful: card games
votesTotal: board games
commentsCount: games of make-believe played in the backyard of my friends' houses when we were five
column16: and
column17: yes
column18: video games that keep/kept me latched onto the idea
column19: entertained
column20:
and engaged in the gameplay.

One thing I quickly learned in Kairo is that there's not much of a carrot.

I'm going to take this discussion back to Antichamber
column21: for those who have played it. I'd hypothesize that the two are compared often for the similar concept of working through puzzles in complete solitude. But in the Hub of Antichamber
column22: you can see a door marked Exit
column23: though you cannot reach it. In one of the first spawn points
column24: you can see a door behind a barrier marked "The End". There's even the Black Ghost
column25: dancing just out of your reach on certain puzzles. These are all suitable carrots.\n\nKairo is designed in such a way that I have yet to see the carrot; there's not much more than an endless stick. And after almost an hour and a half of playing for no apparent reason
column26: I tired of the game.\n\nOn one last note
column27: for all the endless puzzles in Kairo
column28: there are worlds you walk through that have no puzzles at all. The game has a hint feature
column29: but if you are not so inclined to use it
column30: it's incredibly difficult to discern a puzzle world from a world that's apparently there for your exhaustive visual pleasure."

reviewText:
Before I begin, I have played for more than 0.3 hours, but I played in offline mod. Not very much though, this game made me bored faster than a math lesson can do.


Positives:

- Decent scripting I guess

Negatives:

- Pretty much everything
- Boring gameplay
- No storyline


You spawn in a world with absoutely no clue how you got there. You don't have a name, you don't have a goal, you don't have anything to find. The story is non existing.

Some games can be good even without a clear goal or a background story, but not in this case.

Not only do you have no goal, enemies or purpose in Kairo whatsoever, the puzzles are also simple but yet confusing. You can not interact with anything and you don't have an inventory, meaning that all you can do is move objects by walking towards them, or jump on random platforms in hope that something will happen. Really, really simple puzzles. And when I say it's also confusing, what I mean is, you don't really know why you are doing what you are doing due to the non existing story and the few hints you get doesn't really help that much at all.


Do I recommend this game? No. I don't recommend it to anyone.

People that love adventures, no. The game is as simple as it can be (including the soundtracks and gameplay in general) with nothing to explore or discover at all. You don't even have a purpose or anything to lose. Not even health (no, you can't even die in this game).

People that like puzzle games, no. Again, the puzzles are basic, yet confusing, and you don't really know why you are doing them.

People that love a good storyline, no. There is no story in this game at all.

-------------------

Why people like this is beyond me. I have played many bad games, but this without doubt in my top 5 most boring games ever.

2/10 - Really bad
voteText: 2 of 8 people (25%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
As someone who used to work with mapping for garry's mod I can clearly see that the mapping in this game is terrible. Another problem is that the controls are inexplicably sluggish and you feel as if you're on ice skates while you walk. I thought it might be because of my computer but the framerate is very good and there is no mouse lag so the problem has to be related to the game.
Now, I understand that this game is inspired by yume nikki, but that is no excuse to make the puzzles so obscure without a hint on how to solve them. yume nikki itself was not a finished game you know. All in all, I want to get immersed into the game but the lack of polish and sluggish controls make it impossible to do so.

Until this game is properly polished I can't recommend it.

If the dev wants help with mapping, I would be willing to help if I can, for a small fee of course.

reviewText:
A very atmospheric game both visually and audibly, making for a pleasurable journey to the end. Although puzzle based the puzzles are not so hard (or just guesswork based) as to be annoying. With a little thought all but a couple of the puzzles can be solved in reasonable amount of time (and those that can't belong to the 'achievements' section, so they do not hinder you from completing the game).

I loved the pace of this game, the feeling of being somewhere that matters, perhaps because the game hints through its imagery that the place is somehow significant and that you aren't just wandering around without meaning. There was no rush, no one chasing and it was easy to get from point to point without a lot of walking.

Kairo is a relaxing game to play. Enjoyable too.
I did a lot of walking, did a lot of things. I'm not sure where I was walking, nor what the things I did actually achieved, but I did it. Would recommend if you like puzzles and confusing landscape.
Nice indie game.A surreal andventure with easy riddles.The raphics are poor but its a fun 2 hour adventure

What do Portal, Antichamber, Quantum Conundrum, and...oh hell, why not...Bad Rats have in common?

They are all puzzle games (in some sense), yet they all have character to them, something that brings charm to an otherwise incredibly dull game.

Kairo, on the other hand, has absolutely no character in its' floating stone architecture. I wandered the halls looking for some storyline or meaning to my progress, yet there's absolutely nothing to keep your interest for longer than 10 minutes (except possibly for the achievements). Not even Kairo's architecture is interesting, resembling the surreal cubic design of Assassin's Creed's Animus with all the life sucked out of them.

The game doesn't even redeem itself on its' puzzles, which are ridiculously simple and generic, and yet are still explained in full within the game's hint menu.

I only spent $0.82, and yet I still feel like I wasted my money. Save up and buy a better puzzle/platformer instead.
Fun with three dimensional blocks in muted colors and that is about it.
I felt like I was playing The Stanley Parable" crossed with Serious Sam: The First Encounter. If you like sounds of extreme terror
date: and the feeling that the hints you get
recommended: are trying to destroy your gameplay. You will buy this game. 8/8 Gr8 B8 M8."

This game is not primarily a puzzle game. There is so little to interact with on the map. The graphics are so simple and washed out.  Imagine yourself wandering up and down the corridors of the bleak screenshots you see, and that is pretty much the main point of the game. I really tried to get something out of it, but what a bleak depressing boring game. I tried to warn you.

Kairo is really one of a kind game. It takes a little time to absorb you into its world, but once it does it never lets you leave it. It's an adventure/puzzle game which is kind of easy to finish but extremely hard to master.

There is so much hidden stuff in this game that you'll want to play it again and again. Yet, none of its puzzles is obvious or easy to be seen.

Kairo's alien world is extrordinary unique and beautiful on its own and feels like it came out from 2001's monolith.
This game makes me wich I had an Oculus Rift.

The game has very bad performance for its pretty mediocre graphics. Also, I understand it's an exploration game, but there is just nothing to the game apart from that. You just walk around mindlessly. There is no real story, no substance and nothing to keep you interested in progressing in the game.

So, Kairo. Who are we?\n\nLove children of turn of the century, cubist 3d rendering and island based exploration games? Retro-Future gazing, pre-VR, post-apocalypse lumbering hulk puzzlers? Half the time, with you, I am unaware if you are even puzzeling me at all. Baby I ain't saying your puzzles are obtuse, but when you give me a momentary, fleeting UI, well, baby, I'm as surprised as the YouTube kitten finding out the cake really was a lie. But we can work this out. I wanna know your secrets. Just tell me. Baby just tell me the next 7 and a half hours are going to really rock me, baby. We can make this work.

Also, worth playing all the way through for the secret ending alone!

reviewText: Stark environments and fun puzzles. I really enjoyed the abstract presentation.
Maybe I'm paranoid, as far as I know there are no enemies in this games, but I fear for my life constantly, every corner hides an unknown terror... liking it so far.
Oculus dk2 support please!

As an abstract puzzle game, Kairo is great.  The gameplay is simple yet challenging, and the built-in hint system is helpful enough to point you in the right direction when you're stuck without outright spoiling the puzzle.  However, I think the abstract design makes the story hard to follow (and leaves the player to guess); after finishing the game, I wasn't really sure what it was all about.  Still, that doesn't detract from the gameplay.  If you enjoy puzzle games and want something a little different, I would definitely recommend Kairo.

Pros:
- Otherworldly/alien environment.
- Engaging, abstract, and unique puzzles.
- Good music, which helps set a somewhat ominous and somber tone.

Cons:
- The story was a little *too* abstract.
- Keyboard controls are not remappable, or even listed in full.  For example, the R" key resets you to the room entrance
date: but I found that completely by accident.\n- There is no way to see your progress on collecting the hidden glyphs
recommended: except by collecting more of the glyphs.  I would like to have seen my current progress when the game is paused (such as how the map is displayed)."

reviewText: Surprisingly, this game is a lot of fun! If you like adventure games, you'll definitely want to give this one a shot!

This game is phenomenal. Why haven't you bought it yet? It has everything - atmosphere, puzzles, you name it. My one complaint is that it doesn't really tell you at all what you're doing, so you're left fumbling around trying to solve whatever puzzles it gives you. But some might say that's a good thing, and I can see where they're coming from. My rating for this game: 8/10.
My brain hurts.Don't buy this if you love your brain.I realized that i don't love it.\n\n8/10

This game didn't take too long to finish, but somehow I managed to wait for months in between sessions and forget what was going on.  So I would NOT do that, were I to live life a second time.

This game has a few REALLY killer puzzles, and I am a snob about puzzles, so that is saying something.  I think the number one thing that made this game work is it's utter abstractness.  Many of the best puzzles were fairly simple tasks, but understanding how the mechanisms worked was a challending and engaging task, simply because of the lack of context.

One of the most interesting and unique things about this game is the cool control scheme in which the position where you are standing affects the state of the world.  This is used in a variety of ways, and it somehow manages to make very simple puzzles a lot more engaging.

On the down side, this game was definitely lacking in polish.  Movement was slightly glitchy - especially going up stairs and jumping off walls (which I'm not sure you were supposed to be able to do at all).  There were often cheap looking cracks between blocks that didn't quite touch.  Some icons looked like poorly clipped .pngs.  Just a little rough around the edges.

Also the story" kept getting devastatingly interesting
date: and then leaving you hanging.  Ending was super weird (secret ending was even weirder.  But no

reviewText: An interesting game - I actually like games where the controls are limited as it doesn't leave me thinking, Was I supposed to pick up Item A to combine with Item B and use it on Location C?"  The only question I kept asking myself was "Who poured all this concrete?""

I personally love games that are about exploration and  open to interpretation. When I found Kairo and read that it advertised both aspects within its experience, I was instantly bought.

Kairo doesn't offer much in explanation. Every where you go is pretty much bathed in a single chromatic color with plain textures adorning every strange shape of your enviroment. This strangeness is accentuated even more with its plain droning music that is more akin to white noise. There is no death in Kairo either. There is no way to fail in Kairo. In Kairo it is just you, your mind and Kairo.

Now, what exactly is Kairo and why are you there? To understand these things you must venture into your new world. Kairo is seperated into hubs, within in those hubs are different rooms that contain a puzzle. Solve the puzzles and move on to the next hub until you reach the end. That's your goal. The puzzles themselves are not the most complicated thing to accomplish, pull a switch, push a block, align a grid ect and if you ever find yourself stuck there are also helpful hints in the options!

Other than getting to the end there are a few other things to accomplish as detailed by the achievements. Scattered throughout Kairo are 18 runes to collect, a few beacons to activate and a couple of tricky secrety puzzles to solve. I personally feel that if you are invested even in the slightist for Kairo's world then these extra goals should be mandatory for players to solve. The reward in narritive and overall experience trumps the extra hour or two one puts in to accomplish these goals. A helpful tip/warning though, always make sure you collect all the glyphs in an area before moving on! Backtracking for glyphs can be a pain in the ♥♥♥! And if you must backtrack wait until the last hub!

Overall Kairo is a very very short game. This is a good thing though as with such games you will find yourself thinking more about the world as apposed to the gameplay. Kairo is very good food for your brain and whether it's on sale or for the normal five dollars trust me if you like exploration and mystery this is a fantastic deal.
Very nice MYST-like game.\nThe complete lack of plot and the music, along with the graining overlay, make it a game to be played with headphones and with the lights off O_O

Kairo is as different from any mainstream games as can be, and reminds me the most of the very first Myst, which did not in any way indicate what exactly the player is supposed to do. There is no hand-holding, and as such, the entire world of Kairo feels very different, more relaxed and engaging, than you regular game of today.\n\nThe art direction is minimalist, but a lot of thought went into creating the environments. Ultimately, it is a game of exploration and contemplation. Be warned!

Amazingly eerie and amtospheric puzzle game. If you like being thrown into the middle of a surreal landscape and having to figure things in the old-school way, i.e. without tips, object highlights or prompts, then you'll love this game.

Kairo is an interesting, if ultimately slight, atmospheric puzzle game.  The artwork is all rectangles and circles and simple geometric shapes.  The music exists simply to generate atmosphere.  There is no plot
date: but rather a series of puzzles that are to be completed simply because they exist. In addition the secret" puzzles are a pretty big step up in difficulty and will likely resort to the user having to consult a guide.\n\nAll of that said
recommended: the game succeeds with what it's trying to do.  The atmosphere is engrossing and engaging and the game is neither too easy or too difficult.  It's really a shame it was only 3-4 hours long

reviewText:
Kairo is a game about exploration and puzzle-solving, but it is also much more than that. Kairo is something that demands your full attention. It is a game that you play in the dark, all alone. You won't be killing zombies or assassinating kings in Kairo, but you will be exploring a strange, impossible world filled with perplexing architecture.

The ambiance is unsettling, and even threatening at times. The music (written by Wounds) is alienating and absolutely beautiful. The graphics are simple, but this simplicity fits in perfectly in making you feel that you are truly in a foreign world; a place you do not understand. For those of us with low end computers, you'll find this to be a pleasantly smooth running game.

At its core Kairo is a puzzle game. Some puzzles are easy and won't strain you too badly, but others are so hard it's almost unrealistic to think any player could solve them on their own (looking at you, Clock Room). Each puzzle is intuitive though, and they always make sense after you solve them (even you, Clock Room).
Luckily if you get hopelessly stuck, each puzzle has three hints and the solution to help you along.

The story is what really ties the elements of Kairo together. From the start you'll have many questions: Where am I? Why am I here? WHO am I? Will these questions be answered? Well, that depends on you. There is little to no dialogue in Kairo. The story is expressed entirely through the environment and the things that you see. If you want to understand this place you're in, then you must actively think about the actions you take, and how they're affecting the world around you. There are answers to your questions, but Kairo leaves it entirely up to you to find them. If you take the time to uncover the mystery, you'll be glad that you did.

Kairo is a game that not everyone will love. But for those who do, it is a masterpiece. It is the kind of game that sticks with you long after you finish it. I wholeheartedly recommend Kairo.
Minimalist exploration puzzle game. Plays in the same vein as antichamber or naissancee. The world is beautifully designed and the puzzles will make you think.

Kairo is a game about exploration and puzzle solving. If Myst had been made in this generation, I think Kairo is a pretty good representation of what it would play like (though Kairo chose a much more abstract blocky appearance in many areas).\n\nOne of the really cool things about this game is that there is really no dependence on language. There are no conversations and no written or spoken instructions or clues in-game. Aside from the menu and the credits, you don't even need to be literate. The only reading" deals with symbol-matching and it's in the context of numbers
date: not words.\n\nI jumped right into Kairo without researching it at all
recommended: and honestly that's what I'd recommend everybody do. Seriously

Surreal and unnerving, Kairo is a short exploration and puzzle game that revels in the abstract.  Puzzles are straightforward, and the in-game hint system for the rare moment when you get stuck is actually useful.  There is no direct plot, and like a lot of quiet exploration games, it leaves a lot of the storyline interpretation up to the player.  The atmosphere becomes increasingly skin-crawling and nerve-wracking as you go further into the game, and there are one or two moments that are jump scares.  There are no enemies, no health, deaths, or traps.  It is simply the player and the environment, and your goal is to move forward and explore the dream-like world you have been deposited into.

I wanted a peaceful exploration/puzzle-solving game, and that's what Kairo gave me. Unfortunately I found the graphics extremely hard on my eyes - it triggered a lot of motion sickness and headaches for me. I also found some of the puzzles to be really, really obtuse and frustrating. There's also a total lack of a story, which was fine for me but might not be for you. If you're a genre fan, definitely give this a shot. If you're looking for something fast-paced and action-packed, look elsewhere

Also, if you dislike the lag that people have been talking about it's actually Look Smoothing" not lagging so just go to options and disable "Look Smoothing" and the lag should disappear."
Quite cool in its own minimalistic way

A solid 4 or 5 hours of exploration. The puzzles sometimes feel a bit arbitrary, but its unlikely you'll find yourself totally stuck. Overall, Kairo creates a really cool environment to get lost in, which isn't something a lot of new games provide. It may seem a bit boring on the surface, but if you're patient I'm sure you can get something out of it.

It's like a mixture of Fez and Antichamber, and while Kairo may not be as good as either of them, it's still a good game in its own right. The lack of an interact button may seem odd at first, but it allows for some intuitive mechanics. Overall, not a classic but still good enough to justify its low pricing and it's certainly fun while it lasts.

Monoliths, glyphs, runes, buttons to step on... Kairo.

For every step you take in this lonely world, you find yourself seemingly stuck and lost within yourself as well. Film grain covers your field of vision as you navigate the towers, solving a wide plethora of puzzles, from simple navigation of a simple maze to interpreting a star map just to open a door to running on treadmills, Kairo does the puzzle genre justice by infusing complex and mind-boggling puzzles towards a simplistic, minimalist world. The colours are beautiful, the gameplay is relatively solid (although I personally find the movement a little too sensitive) and this is really immersive by itself (if you play in a dark room with headphones).

A drawback for me personally was that I found myself getting lost most of the time, that I was unable to have a good view of the puzzle I'm trying to solve. Like a rat in a maze, I could not see the big picture of the puzzle and I had to keep walking in circles trying to figure out what I've done, even resorting to sketching out some rooms on a piece of paper and drawing the various interactive elements on the paper so I can figure out what in the world is going on. It does interrupt the flow of the game for me sometimes and it was a little distracting to the overall feel of the game.

In short, despite the few rough edges of this work of art, Kairo is really a beautiful gameset (with its fair share of really, really creepy elements and depictions here and there), really meant for the casual player to play and enjoy this surreal world, while unraveling a terrible tale that led to this place. If you're a puzzle nut and you enjoy creepy, lonely worlds, Kairo really is the place for you to be.

Kairo is one of the most beautiful, creative and surreal FPS Adventure/Puzzle games ever made!\nIt's like exploring a living machine on another world :-)\nIt is my favorite game so far on Steam and otherwise!!!!

This is a pretty engaging exploration game. I can recommend it for a low price. It kept me entertained for a day.\nThe atmosphere is superbly crafted. Puzzles are not particularly challenging - it is very much an atmospheric exploration game.
Buy this game. Do not watch a let's play, I'd even recommend against watching the trailer. If you like not too hard puzzles and a very mysterious, slightly creepy atmosphere, buy it.

This game is simply breathtaking. Though it looks a bit barren when you look at the screenshots, you'll be completely drawn in as soon as you play it. The atmospheric soundtrack, the vast landscapes, the mystical ruins, the immensely huge monuments, the surreal locations and the mystical ancient machineries will haunt you in your dreams. This game is a MUST!

I beat Kairo in just a bit over 3 hours, but it is a really incredible game.  It has an excellent atmosphere, brilliantly approachable level design, and interesting yet solvable puzzles. Absolutely worth $5
Very unique gaming experience\n\nMust play
Fantastic.\n\nI see hardly anyone owning this game, but it's pretty spectacular. Please buy it.
[LOW DRONE INTENSIFIES]

Kairo is one of the most beautiful, creative and surreal FPS Adventure/Puzzle games ever made!\nIt's like exploring a living machine on another world :-)\nIt is my favorite game so far on Steam and otherwise!!!!
Quite cool in its own minimalistic way

A solid 4 or 5 hours of exploration. The puzzles sometimes feel a bit arbitrary, but its unlikely you'll find yourself totally stuck. Overall, Kairo creates a really cool environment to get lost in, which isn't something a lot of new games provide. It may seem a bit boring on the surface, but if you're patient I'm sure you can get something out of it.

It's like a mixture of Fez and Antichamber, and while Kairo may not be as good as either of them, it's still a good game in its own right. The lack of an interact button may seem odd at first, but it allows for some intuitive mechanics. Overall, not a classic but still good enough to justify its low pricing and it's certainly fun while it lasts.

Monoliths, glyphs, runes, buttons to step on... Kairo.

For every step you take in this lonely world, you find yourself seemingly stuck and lost within yourself as well. Film grain covers your field of vision as you navigate the towers, solving a wide plethora of puzzles, from simple navigation of a simple maze to interpreting a star map just to open a door to running on treadmills, Kairo does the puzzle genre justice by infusing complex and mind-boggling puzzles towards a simplistic, minimalist world. The colours are beautiful, the gameplay is relatively solid (although I personally find the movement a little too sensitive) and this is really immersive by itself (if you play in a dark room with headphones).

A drawback for me personally was that I found myself getting lost most of the time, that I was unable to have a good view of the puzzle I'm trying to solve. Like a rat in a maze, I could not see the big picture of the puzzle and I had to keep walking in circles trying to figure out what I've done, even resorting to sketching out some rooms on a piece of paper and drawing the various interactive elements on the paper so I can figure out what in the world is going on. It does interrupt the flow of the game for me sometimes and it was a little distracting to the overall feel of the game.

In short, despite the few rough edges of this work of art, Kairo is really a beautiful gameset (with its fair share of really, really creepy elements and depictions here and there), really meant for the casual player to play and enjoy this surreal world, while unraveling a terrible tale that led to this place. If you're a puzzle nut and you enjoy creepy, lonely worlds, Kairo really is the place for you to be.

Okay, let's get one thing out of the way first: this game does not look good. The trailer above kinda oversells the graphics — they're not minimalistic, they're cheap.
That being said, everything else about Kairo is great.

Distant cousin of Myst, this game is comprised mostly of puzzles. And there is a compelling diversity in these: some are very easy, some are very difficult; some totally straightforward, some mind-bendingly abstract; and of course everything in between. This makes the progression always enticing and never boring.
The level design is very cool despite the poor graphics and each level has its own unique feel, the whole game being very atmospheric". This is brilliantly reinforced by the marvelous sound design

reviewText: An interesting game - I actually like games where the controls are limited as it doesn't leave me thinking, Was I supposed to pick up Item A to combine with Item B and use it on Location C?"  The only question I kept asking myself was "Who poured all this concrete?""

I personally love games that are about exploration and  open to interpretation. When I found Kairo and read that it advertised both aspects within its experience, I was instantly bought.

Kairo doesn't offer much in explanation. Every where you go is pretty much bathed in a single chromatic color with plain textures adorning every strange shape of your enviroment. This strangeness is accentuated even more with its plain droning music that is more akin to white noise. There is no death in Kairo either. There is no way to fail in Kairo. In Kairo it is just you, your mind and Kairo.

Now, what exactly is Kairo and why are you there? To understand these things you must venture into your new world. Kairo is seperated into hubs, within in those hubs are different rooms that contain a puzzle. Solve the puzzles and move on to the next hub until you reach the end. That's your goal. The puzzles themselves are not the most complicated thing to accomplish, pull a switch, push a block, align a grid ect and if you ever find yourself stuck there are also helpful hints in the options!

Other than getting to the end there are a few other things to accomplish as detailed by the achievements. Scattered throughout Kairo are 18 runes to collect, a few beacons to activate and a couple of tricky secrety puzzles to solve. I personally feel that if you are invested even in the slightist for Kairo's world then these extra goals should be mandatory for players to solve. The reward in narritive and overall experience trumps the extra hour or two one puts in to accomplish these goals. A helpful tip/warning though, always make sure you collect all the glyphs in an area before moving on! Backtracking for glyphs can be a pain in the ♥♥♥! And if you must backtrack wait until the last hub!

Overall Kairo is a very very short game. This is a good thing though as with such games you will find yourself thinking more about the world as apposed to the gameplay. Kairo is very good food for your brain and whether it's on sale or for the normal five dollars trust me if you like exploration and mystery this is a fantastic deal.
Very nice MYST-like game.\nThe complete lack of plot and the music, along with the graining overlay, make it a game to be played with headphones and with the lights off O_O

Kairo isn't fully optimized for lower end PCs, however it's still an incredibly enjoyable experience. The puzzles are nothing overwhelming, giving subliminal hints in-game in an almost instructional manner. I've yet to complete the game, but I'm interested to see what's next.

Kairo is as different from any mainstream games as can be, and reminds me the most of the very first Myst, which did not in any way indicate what exactly the player is supposed to do. There is no hand-holding, and as such, the entire world of Kairo feels very different, more relaxed and engaging, than you regular game of today.\n\nThe art direction is minimalist, but a lot of thought went into creating the environments. Ultimately, it is a game of exploration and contemplation. Be warned!

Intresting artstyle, relativly challenging puzzels, (not so Challenging as MYST but good). It also has a no descript story and strong message in it. Worth getting if its on special but probably wouldn't pay full price for it due to its short gametime (~2 hours), however plenty of secrets to find in it.
Pretty simple but quite nice. Kills boredom for a few hours.
An incredible puzzle game. The ending makes the entire ambient, vaguely unsettling experience of a trek worthwhile. An absolute steal for $5.

Oh Kairo, you're such a strange little piece of minimalistic nothingness. I payed $1.49 for the game on sale and thats exactly how much i feel like its worth. I enjoyed playing the game but at the same time when I was playing I just wanted to get all the achievements and be done with it. The puzzles were fun, the art was beautiful but the game lacked reasoning & excitement. Don't buy for full price.

Wow.

Kairo is absolutely stellar. It is ominous, confusing, ethereal, gorgeous, and fascinating.

The whole time you play, you're kept curious and driven to discover what is going on, and how all the pieces fit together.

The minimalistic design just serves to heighten the sense that this is a strange and alien place. The music, performed by Wounds, lends much of the foreboding nature to the feel of the environments.

There is one puzzle that feels artificially difficult and out of place, but the rest are really organic and are wonderful to solve.

Absolutely worth a play through.

A really atmospheric puzzle and exploration game.  I was very impressed with how the environment and your interactions with it tells the narrative.  I found myself crawling all over the areas in this game.  I really like its style.  Very mysterious and unsettling thanks to the excellent soundtrack.
Nice adventure puzzler.  Completely in vane of Myst yet even more abstract.  No explicit allusions to what is actually going on....you must infer.\n\nGood puzzles and some good secrets.
Majestic, atmospheric, beautifully minimalistic game.
This a decent puzzle/thoughtful game that's good to wait for a steam sale. It's not difficult (and in fact has a hint system) and probably a few hours long.

Kairo is one of those games that doesn't tell you anything, and just let's you figure it all out. It's a good game to play through on a weekend morning. It's a good abstract adventure game with a cool look. Check it out sometime.

If exploration and atmosphere dont matter to you much you can stop reading here and ignore the game completely. If you are like me and appreciate that kind of game Kairo is certainly worth buying. Atmosphere is superb, with every location being unique in its own right yet fitting overall alien feel of this world. Exploration is rewarded with lots of easy to miss details hidden around most locations. To me weakest part of the game were puzzles, while most of them fit perfectly into the theme of each room they were too easy. All in all if you like exploration based games it is great game if you dont like this kind of thing avoid it like plague.
Amazing atmospheric game I'm in love.

There is a special kind of aura surrounding this game, one I haven't seen before in videogames. Not unlike the early forms of dadaism, this is one of the only games (if not the only one) I have ever encountered, that has no pretense whatsoever. It gives you all it has, there's no story hidden behind written texts, there's no gimmicks in the form of fancy graphics or character design, it wants to be a puzzle game, and it is exactly that. Now, you might ask why you might want to buy such a game, which, by my description might seem to have little to offer.

Well, that's exactly it. By reading the other reviews, you'll see that every player got some kind of profound immersive experience out of it. I can ensure you, that the game offers none of this, but not in the sense that it doesn't offer content, but it doesn't contain any subtext whatsoever. It is the blankest slate modern videogaming has seen last years, and it is that which makes it so desirable. Like any good piece of poetry, interpretation is left completely up to the reader, even if the initial piece of art offers little content in itself. Kairo is the 12-verse poem which inspires linguists to write 100-page long critical readings. The quality and rigidity of the gameplay alone are a solid performance, but the way the creators manage to avoid any kind of context or narrative, without sacrificing any immersiveness, is an experience that must be had, and at this price, there's no excuse not to. Plus, it has Oculus Rift support!

Most comparable to Antichamber (gameplay) and Flywrench (premise).

A fantastic indie game. An unique (almost meditative) experience where you slowly uncover the truth and story of this abstract world, by solving clever puzzles and activating each room. The atmosphere can be quite scary and daunting at first, but somehow evolves so you feel peaceful and calm at the end.\n\nLast night I actually dreamt of this game; very odd yet fascinating.
This game is nuts.... very minimalistic and there are parts where you'll think WTF am I supposed to do?" and then it clicks and you go "OOOOhhhhhhhh!!! Damn

reviewText: This game made me feel like I was in an Arthur C. Clarke novel, exploring weird, alien archetecture.  The atmosphere is fantastic and the design is excellent.  Everything (including the interface) is elegant and stripped-down.  I was surprised at how many distinct, memorable places could be made from such simple building blocks.  The puzzles are engaging, but not very difficult; for me, the game was paced exactly right, with no area wearing out its welcome before I was able to move on and see something new.

Need a break?

Welcome to the strange, yet simple and relaxing world of Kairo. It's a world filled with many ambiances, many puzzles, and many secrets.
The gameplay is that simple, reduced to only movements, triggers activating by just pushing or walking passed them. Most of the puzzles also aren't difficult, with hints provided in the menu if you need some help. Though, some secrets are pretty hard to find or solve, and you might want to pass them if you don't want to spend a lot of time on them.
But what makes Kairo different is the collection of ambiances and places, some people might see them like poetry, despite the lack of plot. Of course you will have a hard time enjoying this if you seek action.

Overall, its a nice, short, but most importantly relaxing game.
Be careful though, despite the quite simple graphics, it seems the game needs quite the resource, and you don't have many graphic options to help it.

Kairo just seems like it was made for VR. The best way to describe is it is a Myst like experience where you travel through enormous rooms and areas that are large puzzles to figure out. There's no weaponry, no enemies unless you count the puzzles and you pretty much cannot die (falling off ledges just puts you back on the ledge). Each room is dominated by a simple color scheme and the architecture is large and blocky as giving the environment an ancient feel.

When played on a normal monitor, the simple graphics and plain architecture might seem like a negative. However, you activate VR, put on the Rift and you realize these graphics are now a strength. Just as Valve Steam Dev Days demo showed, so long as you keep latency low and frame rate high even a simple environment will seem real. Kairo delivers on this concept in spades. The large throne rooms, invisible maze arena, hollow pyramids, giant light orb and many other breathtaking sites fill this game. The slow pace and not too mind bending puzzles mean you're seeing new areas yet have plenty of time to appreciate each one. The sounds are different for each location and all are relaxing and never seem to be over bearing or painfully loud. There are a few cases where the sudden movement of the environment surprised me, but never did I feel the need to pull out of the game. The presence is strong and even with lengthy gameplay I did not notice much if any in the way of nausea. The frame rate seems great throughout with only one room (the one with four treadmills) showing lag.

Like Dear Esther, I play this game standing up and do the fake foot walk to aid in my immersion. The look is not tied to the control movement so it's easy to look around and enjoy the environment as you travel through. Its very easy to get drawn into the game and forget that you're in your room playing a game.

People probably have missed that this is a VR game as it does not seem to have the VR Support" tag in the Steam search function. I've written the author and asked if he can get that added. As I said
date: for only $5 you're getting several hours of a great VR experience. A perfect game for those that prefer relaxed gameplay over the horror or shooter style games currently listed with VR support."

reviewText: An interesting game - I actually like games where the controls are limited as it doesn't leave me thinking, Was I supposed to pick up Item A to combine with Item B and use it on Location C?"  The only question I kept asking myself was "Who poured all this concrete?""

I personally love games that are about exploration and  open to interpretation. When I found Kairo and read that it advertised both aspects within its experience, I was instantly bought.

Kairo doesn't offer much in explanation. Every where you go is pretty much bathed in a single chromatic color with plain textures adorning every strange shape of your enviroment. This strangeness is accentuated even more with its plain droning music that is more akin to white noise. There is no death in Kairo either. There is no way to fail in Kairo. In Kairo it is just you, your mind and Kairo.

Now, what exactly is Kairo and why are you there? To understand these things you must venture into your new world. Kairo is seperated into hubs, within in those hubs are different rooms that contain a puzzle. Solve the puzzles and move on to the next hub until you reach the end. That's your goal. The puzzles themselves are not the most complicated thing to accomplish, pull a switch, push a block, align a grid ect and if you ever find yourself stuck there are also helpful hints in the options!

Other than getting to the end there are a few other things to accomplish as detailed by the achievements. Scattered throughout Kairo are 18 runes to collect, a few beacons to activate and a couple of tricky secrety puzzles to solve. I personally feel that if you are invested even in the slightist for Kairo's world then these extra goals should be mandatory for players to solve. The reward in narritive and overall experience trumps the extra hour or two one puts in to accomplish these goals. A helpful tip/warning though, always make sure you collect all the glyphs in an area before moving on! Backtracking for glyphs can be a pain in the ♥♥♥! And if you must backtrack wait until the last hub!

Overall Kairo is a very very short game. This is a good thing though as with such games you will find yourself thinking more about the world as apposed to the gameplay. Kairo is very good food for your brain and whether it's on sale or for the normal five dollars trust me if you like exploration and mystery this is a fantastic deal.
Very nice MYST-like game.\nThe complete lack of plot and the music, along with the graining overlay, make it a game to be played with headphones and with the lights off O_O

I'm not sure what to think of this game.  What I am sure of is that this game is not for me.  This game should feel open, mysterious, provoke exploration and thought.  That is not what I got.  What I encountered was hazy polluted visuals, vague aimless concepts, a feeling of hemmed in oppression and a headache.  I felt trapped in an environment that was hot, dry and without purpose, bombarding my senses with noise and unclear locals.\nI am surprised to say this but this game has projected an image of what could be my own personal hell.\nI can see that there are a lot of people who love this game, but I didn't find it enjoyable, and couldn't even stand an hour of it.  Look to others if you want a positive side of this game, but I can't recommend it.
It makes you feel alone, as if in a part of space where only you and the world exist... well untill you find a skeleton, then you know you're probably gonna die.

Summary:  Interesting indie first-person puzzle game with terrible mechanics, its only redeeming quality is its unique atmosphere that is breathtaking modern art at times, but can be grating at others.

Pros:Unique and thought provoking styling and ambiance
Unique puzzles (some hard, others stupid easy)
Minimalist
Grand and wide open environments
Nostalgic 90s feel (at least to me)Cons:The intense color palette, sharp and grating sound effects, and an overall feeling of confusion makes the game interesting at first and then unpleasant
Many of the puzzles are either confusing, super easy, or boring
Terrible game engine (slow, buggy, see though walls and objects)
Because the game is so grand and wide open you zoom around at 100mph across vast areas which is annoying at times
Very unpolished
Fairly short Detailed review:  I played this game almost back-to-back with Qbeh-1, a first-person puzzle game in the same vein. It was a funny coincidence because, in juxtaposition, these games couldn’t be further opposites. Qbeh-1 fosters a zen relaxed feeling with blue skies, cool water, open spaces, majestic buildings, relaxing ambient music, and a feeling of smooth progression using hands-on puzzles with standard building blocks. Kairo on the other hand is a strange game with a surreal, Stonehenge, modern abstract,  David Smith Cubi [www.guggenheim.org] feeling with graphics reminiscent of the 90s era (reminded me of an old dos game called S.C.A.R.A.B.). It has an environment that is discomforting and disconcerting, trapping the player in dark psychedelic tombs and inorganic voids. The game uses harsh grating sound effects and music and surrounds the player with static filled screens, sharp abstract constructions, and bizarre features. There are no controls beyond the basic movement controls; every “action” is performed by stepping on tiles or otherwise bumping into the various features found within the giant rooms. Perfecting the feeling of being lost in an abstract void is a complete lack of storyline or instruction beyond a list of puzzle hints that can be found in the menu. In short, the game makes you feel like you’re traveling through the monolith from 2001: A Space Odyssey. It’s not bad, but I wouldn’t recommend it to just anyone as it would offend all but those who can appreciate a game that is little more than a virtual modern art gallery with simple puzzles separating each exhibit.

Kairo is a fantastical art piece, with a very neat style, Oculous Rift capability, captivating and overly inclusive puzzles, all wrapped in a simple cubic atmosphere and relaxing music.
The price you pay for this is pretty worth it, its not too steep, not too steep at all. I mean, spare 5 bucks and give your brain a teaser or two.

The Problems I find with Kairo is the story, I will be honest, I dunno at all what is going on, don't mean it don't captivate me though! The devs of Kairo claim there is a deep story that will make the most sense when you're at the end of the game. I dunno bout that, but its none the less a fun game to play when you wanna give your brain a challenging but very relaxing exercise!

Graphics = 7/10
Story = 5/10
Challenges = 9/10
Artistic Licence = 10/10
Music = 10/10

Overall = 7/10 would reccomend only if you really wanna get a good brain teaser!
Kairo is a beautiful and enigmatic game when your purpose is never explained, and the only thin that push you forward is the vague notion of progression.

People say that Kairo's familiar to the Myst but it's certainly not. Heavy atmosphere of the famous series is nothing like building a new better world from the scratch. It's a fulfilling job that's for sure. Try it for yourself.

Kairo was an amazing game, from its beautiful scenery to the helpful message at the end. I found it quite spooky being alone the entire time, but it certainly gave it a sense of wonder and the feeling of emptiness. I was kinda iffy about this game at first and some of the puzzles are tricky, but the atmosphere and the soundtrack are absolutely worth it.\nThe soundtrack absolutely helps the game and its amazingly eerie. If you want the soundtrack, you can get it on iTunes for $10.

I loved the fact that you don't have an action button it's just good old fashion pushing or jumping on. It's a small detail, but still, it's not usual and I think it brings something unique to this game.

Also the visuals, I loved them, but I also loved the images in the steam store page, here's a tip: the visuals are right there, you don't get a LOT more than that, it's all squares and different colors, if you don't like the images you might not like the visuals in the game.

Highly recommended if you are into Adventure genre. This is for Myst what Guernica" is for "Mona Lisa"

reviewText:
There are two ways to approach Kairo. The first is to view it as a meditative experience in an open world with many soothing  environments and lots of exploration. The second view is to see it as a string of puzzles that need to be solved to complete and beat the game.

You'll enjoy it either way you view it. If you decide to explore, you will see many different areas, and come to love the fact that you can hide away in the world of Kairo and relax after a long day. Walk around in the Park, look at the alien structures, and relax to the calm sounds of water rushing, or birds chirping.


And if you take it as a string of puzzles, you will be challenged with a system with no interaction button, with clues to guide you when you are lost. You will push things, pull things, and eventually get the machines that govern the world of Kairo running.

And be treated to a delightful and uplifting ending.
Surprisingly, this game is a lot of fun! If you like adventure games, you'll definitely want to give this one a shot!
Atmosphere.  Puzzles.  Achievements.  It's an incredible short puzzle game, that really made me feel immersed in a world.  I enjoyed my playthrough.

Kairo is an interesting, if ultimately slight, atmospheric puzzle game.  The artwork is all rectangles and circles and simple geometric shapes.  The music exists simply to generate atmosphere.  There is no plot
date: but rather a series of puzzles that are to be completed simply because they exist.  The puzzles are generally fairly easy, although there are no real instructions and most of the puzzles require you to use your surroundings to figure out what to do.  In addition the secret" puzzles are a pretty big step up in difficulty and will likely resort to the user having to consult a guide.\n\nAll of that said
recommended: the game succeeds with what it's trying to do.  The atmosphere is engrossing and engaging and the game is neither too easy or too difficult.  It's really a shame it was only 3-4 hours long
hoursPlayed: 'cause I think it could have been twice as long and not worn out its welcome.\n\nRating: 8/10"

reviewText: As some of the reviewers say, Kairo is... odd. It feels a bit like exploring the inside of someone's mind.\n\nI found it fascinating.
Simple, yet intericate, I highly recommend it for the puzzles.

First things first KAIRO is a straight up Puzzler.
It isn't really anything else, especially barely a game of exploration.
What i think is really good in that regard is that it doesn't seem to lock you into a puzzle.


There is somewhat of an part exploration in the gameplay but it doesn't really reward you for it.
Yes, i know you can find some kind of runes, however that isn't really what i want to be rewarded with when it comes to exploration.

What i want from exploring a world is interesting and inspiring sites and views and in that regard Kairo is rather weak.


One reason why i feel that way is simply taste. :-P
The overall world design is far to abstrcat for my taste,
The structures in Kairo simply feel to artificial wich leads to me thinking well
recommended: intersting design dear gamedesigner" instead of loosing myself in the world and inspiring thougths like "what may have happened here" or "i wonder what this once was".\nOn top of that many elements of the world look really rather unfitting in their surroundings instead of giving me the feeling that they are a naturall part of this structures.
hoursPlayed:
The design simply lacks a conclusive and whole overall direction.

The second reason is that Kairo is really rather crude and unpolished.
Don't get too close to the walls becasue the camera will clip trough the walls.
Strange lighting effects that most likely weren't suppossed to be there or even look like the textures have been placed wrong are visible in the VERY FIRST rooms you will explore in the game.

But the worst are the textures overall. They look really
voteText:
really HORRIBBLE!
It really pulls you out of the experience if you can count the pixels of what is suppossed to be cracks and holes in walls.

The second weakness is Kairos Sonddesign or rather the lack thereoff. There are sounds and noises but they are more annoying then enriching and in many places sounds simply a re missing where there should have been some noice.
If giant structures in the world are moving i shouldn't feel like they are made of Styrophor and have no weight to them. Wich is exactly what happens in Kairo.

Kairo wants to be a minimalist thing but minimalistic doesn't mean low quality of assets and i feel that is what has been confused here when Kairo was designed.

Would i recommend it?

Nah
