reviewText: This first-person puzzle game relies on a minimalist, surreal environment to pull you in...but boy does it deliver.  I think if you liked Myst, you'll like this game...wandering around a vast, abandoned landscape fiddling with technology you don't understand.  But the game's not about the fiddling...it's about the wandering and the discovery (you'll know what to fiddle when the time comes).  If you like exploring and the visual style appeals to you (watch the video) then definitely pick this up.\n\nI'm going to come back and flesh out this review more, but for now, I want to make a note of the fact that the coolest thing about Kairo, for me, was the ambience of the environments.  It was quite Myst-like in that it created this constant sense of wonder at the surreal landscapes.

Smart, unusual, inventive and weirdly beautiful. The atmosphere is captivating, every room is distinctive and fun to explore, puzzles are smart, not too hard, and interesting to solve. The entire experience is really well-paced and the background music closes the deal.  Definetely a YES for anybody who digs a different kind of game every once in a while.

I bought this on sale for less than 1€, but I'd happily have paid the full price for it. it's an extremely minimalistic game, don't buy it if you absolutely need captivating plots, high-end graphics and complex gameplay or you'd be disappointed. the game is a fascinating journey through a beautifully designed surrealistic world. a really fitting ambient soundtrack adds a lot to the experience. if you've ever played Hiversaires and enjoyed it you'll really like this game as well (if you haven't go and play it). despite the 90s-like 3d graphics I was more than once amazed by the haunting and eerie scenarios and architecture of the game. along the journey you have to solve puzzles to proceed, which are decent, full of satisfying eureka-moments and quite never frustrating. it's a pretty short game tho, it took me less than 3 hours to get to the final credits, but still there were a couple of optional puzzles I didn't solve and some secrets I discovered that suggest there is something more if you find them all, so I might get back to it one day. one last note: most of the negative reviews complain about the lack of a plot and clear instructions. well I liked that instead, it's a plot device itself that adds to the unsettling feel of the game. you're thrown in without any explanation and are left with more questions than answers. picture it as a dream, no one is there to tell you where you are, what is happening and what you have to do, you just accept it and go on, and it's beautiful that way.\n\noverall solid 7.5/10, would play again.

Yes game, when walk through your rooms I appreciate your post-modernist, minimalist design that recalls Egyptian, Chinese and Classical art. But when you place these puzzle-less rooms in between the puzzles, you're really hurting the pacing. Though for $0.74 (as of this writing) , I definitely recommend picking it up. The puzzles are just challenging enough and if you have trouble the game has a pretty generous hint system.

Kairo is beautiful, plain and simple. It is an adventure from the begining. Not because of the adrenaline injections most games rely on and many gamers are addicted to. Everything is so carefully placed as to invoke a sense of haunting and ancient beauty. The game reminds me of a ghost story. Your character is in search of a ghost (let's say the ghost of his wife.) His search has led him to the ancient temple where all spirits reside. He must return life to all of the spirits in the temple to find his wife. Bad fanfiction aside, this game is pure genius and I want all of my friends to play it.

What do Portal, Antichamber, Quantum Conundrum, and...oh hell, why not...Bad Rats have in common?

They are all puzzle games (in some sense), yet they all have character to them, something that brings charm to an otherwise incredibly dull game.

Kairo, on the other hand, has absolutely no character in its' floating stone architecture. I wandered the halls looking for some storyline or meaning to my progress, yet there's absolutely nothing to keep your interest for longer than 10 minutes (except possibly for the achievements). Not even Kairo's architecture is interesting, resembling the surreal cubic design of Assassin's Creed's Animus with all the life sucked out of them.

The game doesn't even redeem itself on its' puzzles, which are ridiculously simple and generic, and yet are still explained in full within the game's hint menu.

I only spent $0.82, and yet I still feel like I wasted my money. Save up and buy a better puzzle/platformer instead.

reviewText: This isn't even really a game, its kinda like walking around in a world like the PS2 startup screen. There are puzzles but most of them are fairly simple; the atmosphere is the real reason I liked this. If you just like the idea of getting lost in a strange place and trying to make sense of it then this might interest you.

Kairo is a beautifully eerie shapescape that combines original style with familiar puzzle questing.  It is a simple yet aw- filled atmospheric journey that takes place in this supernatural-like world you've stumbled upon.

Pros:
+ Increadible atmosphere.  Sometimes even daunting to look at with the great depth of field use by the dev.
+ Music is more like a drone in various keys and melodies.  It's unique and quite pleasing to listen to.
+ There is no linearity to it, well there is but you're free to tackle various areas at your leisure.
+ Puzzles are both easy and incredibly challenging.
+ Sandbox style freedom to explore the world.  It's not very large but the amount of rooms can make you forget where to go or where you've been.

Cons:
- There is very little if any backstory but some may say none is needed with just how odd and abstract the setting is.
- Some puzzles are a little too tough because they go completely unexplained or not elluded to.

Overall I would rate this game a solid 8/10.  If you're into puzzles and don't mind exploring abstract scenery with no AI interaction then this game is 100% worth it at it's price.  On sale even better.  I highly recommend it.

This game is pretty crazy. Somewhere between fascinating and terrifying, wondrous and foreboding. There are no monsters or even imminent threats really, but still your entire surroundings feel so ancient and so much grander than you that it creates an incredibly ominous feeling that never quite goes away.

As you interact with the world, huge abandoned structures come to life, and though the scenery changes and the paths are made clear, you never really know what’s going on under the surface. What do these huge contraptions actually do? Where is it leading? And how did all of it (and you for that matter) end up here? You get the sense that you’ll never really know, because it’s all just too ancient, too alien for your understanding.

The entire experience is rather chilling, and if you let yourself really become immersed in this world, you’ll probably find yourself making some pretty strange sounds, like I was, and laughing at points about just how uncomfortable it actually makes you.

The game isn’t perfect. There are bugs, but those tend to add to the strangeness of the environment in a way. One noticeable fault I had was that the footstep sounds are the exact same no matter what your pace is. This may sound minor, but it is rather noticeable at times when you are really taking it slow to take in your surroundings, which you will probably do quite a lot. Still a minor complaint in face of everything that’s really on display in this one.

I bought it during a Summer Sale at $1.50, and I would probably recommend it at a fairly higher price-tag even still.

reviewText: I bought this looking for a pure exploration/discovery game, was not disappointed. Fantastic game.

Quite possibly one of the more abstract puzzle games I've played. No direction given, and some very strange puzzles to solve just by observing the environment. Luckily there are a few puzzles you don't have to solve to complete the storyline (whatever that was exactly). But I did rather enjoy the atmosphere, and found it rather relaxing.

What a fantastic game. Smooth gameplay, intriguing storyline, simple atmosphere, and yet challenging . Definitely a game I would recommend to a friend. 10/10
I loved that I never felt rushed to complete any of the puzzles and that I never felt that you needed a trick" to complete a puzzle (only looked at a walkthrough guide twice on first playthrough). Observation is your best friend in the game. Its nice to know you can go back to the begining at any point to recheck for runes or secrets missed.
There are no real negatives as I thoroughly enjoyed the game. Some people might find it a bit short but finding ALL secrets will take a bit of effort.
All-in-all a game I glad I took the time to play."

Oh Kairo, you're such a strange little piece of minimalistic nothingness. I payed $1.49 for the game on sale and thats exactly how much i feel like its worth. I enjoyed playing the game but at the same time when I was playing I just wanted to get all the achievements and be done with it. The puzzles were fun, the art was beautiful but the game lacked reasoning & excitement. Don't buy for full price.

Wow.

Kairo is absolutely stellar. It is ominous, confusing, ethereal, gorgeous, and fascinating.

The whole time you play, you're kept curious and driven to discover what is going on, and how all the pieces fit together.

The minimalistic design just serves to heighten the sense that this is a strange and alien place. The music, performed by Wounds, lends much of the foreboding nature to the feel of the environments.

There is one puzzle that feels artificially difficult and out of place, but the rest are really organic and are wonderful to solve.

Absolutely worth a play through.

reviewText: An interesting game - I actually like games where the controls are limited as it doesn't leave me thinking, Was I supposed to pick up Item A to combine with Item B and use it on Location C?"  The only question I kept asking myself was "Who poured all this concrete?""

I personally love games that are about exploration and  open to interpretation. When I found Kairo and read that it advertised both aspects within its experience, I was instantly bought.

Kairo doesn't offer much in explanation. Every where you go is pretty much bathed in a single chromatic color with plain textures adorning every strange shape of your enviroment. This strangeness is accentuated even more with its plain droning music that is more akin to white noise. There is no death in Kairo either. There is no way to fail in Kairo. In Kairo it is just you, your mind and Kairo.

Now, what exactly is Kairo and why are you there? To understand these things you must venture into your new world. Kairo is seperated into hubs, within in those hubs are different rooms that contain a puzzle. Solve the puzzles and move on to the next hub until you reach the end. That's your goal. The puzzles themselves are not the most complicated thing to accomplish, pull a switch, push a block, align a grid ect and if you ever find yourself stuck there are also helpful hints in the options!

Other than getting to the end there are a few other things to accomplish as detailed by the achievements. Scattered throughout Kairo are 18 runes to collect, a few beacons to activate and a couple of tricky secrety puzzles to solve. I personally feel that if you are invested even in the slightist for Kairo's world then these extra goals should be mandatory for players to solve. The reward in narritive and overall experience trumps the extra hour or two one puts in to accomplish these goals. A helpful tip/warning though, always make sure you collect all the glyphs in an area before moving on! Backtracking for glyphs can be a pain in the ♥♥♥! And if you must backtrack wait until the last hub!

Overall Kairo is a very very short game. This is a good thing though as with such games you will find yourself thinking more about the world as apposed to the gameplay. Kairo is very good food for your brain and whether it's on sale or for the normal five dollars trust me if you like exploration and mystery this is a fantastic deal.

If you're looking for a deep, challenging puzzle game with an ambiguous and surreal atmosphere, then have another go at using that search box because you seem to have mispelled Antichamber. I wouldn't mention it, except you can't seem to go 5 minutes of reading about this game without it being compared to Antichamber (indeed, this comparison is what brought me to the game in the first place), and I simply can't see why. Kairo is nothing like Antichamber, and if you're expecting it to be then you're about to be sorely disappointed. This is not to say that I didn't like Kairo, as you can presumably tell from the fact that this review is a recommendation. reviewText: Sweet puzzle game
Not the worst game in the world, but for the most part its just some very nice looking scenery to jump around with a fe puzzles scattered about.

I quite enjoyed this game. The atmosphere was great, and it looked really cool. However, some of the puzzles were a bit -too- abstract, and for some reason touching a wall caused my framerate to drop dramatically. This got annoying in some areas, espeically being that the controls in this game aren't very tight, even with the settings tweaked.

Some areas a a bit bigger than they need to be, so there's a lot of walking to do. Thank goodness there's a sprint button, but it doesn't change your speed that much.

This game has very little replay value, unless you're one of those people who want to painstakingly go through every nook and cranny to find these tiny symbols tucked in corners of the levels.

I think the game was trying to tell me a story, but I didn't get any sort of feeling of resolution at the end, unless I am supposed to find all those little symbols. That sounds absolutely miserable though. That would be like playing a 3d eye spy game. I have better things to do with my life.

Overall, I enjoyed the game. Puzzles were nice, except for a few, which were really stupidly hard. The game is not that long at all, so these few dark spots really put a dent in the overall experience.

I almost gave this a thumbs down, but at the end of the day, it did hold my attention, and I did say twice in this review that I enjoyed it, so it gets a thumbs up from me. But just barely.

Minimalist, abstract, and esoteric. I picked up a copy of Kairo because it was on sale and it looked interesting and played it through to completion (with the help of a guide to point me in the direction of my objectives, I admit. They're not that obvious some of the time).

Kairo manages to combine my two least favorite things in a game: slippery controls and almost required sprinting. In-game you can hear your footsteps so I know my feet weren't covered in oil... but it certainly felt like it. Many of the areas are expansive, which is cool, but if you want to try to complete the game the way I did you will need to backtrack through areas you've already visited. At times like these I found myself holding down the sprint key just to get through these areas as fast as possible. After about an hour of this, my left hand is pretty sore.

On the positive side the environments were cool and my favorite puzzle mechanic- the block puzzles where you have to stand in a certain position in the room to solve them- didn't feel like it was used often enough. I think there's enough in that idea alone to make an entire game out of, should the developer give it a try.

That said I cannot, in good faith, recommend Kairo. Not at full price, anyway. Five bucks for a ~3 hour game that's uncomfortable to play during the second half isn't a great deal by any stretch of the imagination.

reviewText: Kairo, hell of a weird game. I bought it couple of months back, but I only got around to playing it today. I have to say, it is a trippy and weird game. There isn't really a objective, though there are things to do, yet they are very bizarre and unclear at times, though the hint option makes it much easier. Hints, though, are infinite and makes the game a breeze, I would suggest avoiding hints to immerse yourself. The environments are simple, yet beautiful. Also, the isolation and the sheer loneliness that this game brings is very eerie and makes you think anything could pop out at any moment, though, nothing.\n\nI would very much recommend this game. I haven't finished playing it, but at a first glance, this game could give you immersion and isolation similar to Aliens: Isolation and Everybody's Gone to the Rapture.
Awesome game.

This is a good game. But it had FAR MORE potential. It all felt like it was leading up to something really spectacular and then.. the end. That being said, I really, REALLY like what the end is all about, it just caught me off guard, that's all.

I did really enjoy my time playing Kairo ^.^ It's all very smooth and I hardly found any of the puzzles too difficult. Perhaps the best thing about this game is the atmosphere it creates. I often didn't realize how much time was passing in the real world as I played it.

There are some hidden bonuses to find after completing the game and those were fun to search for as well.

8/10

In my opinoin, Kairo is an okay game. It tries to blend confusion and beauty, but ends up being a mess. Some puzzles are easy to solve, but others have no direction and are almost unsolvable if it weren't for google and the fourms.

First, I'll start off with the puzzles. As I said, some are good brainteasers or just require good reflexes, but some made absolutely no sense. Sometimes I find myself scrambling around the current area looking for clues and hidden messages when the only task I have is to walk forward. Often, I find hidden messages that have no meaning, and I end up trying to figure out the purpose. Some harder puzzles had me pulling my hair out in frustration, which, in my opinion is okay. The problem is that I end up resorting to Google or the fourms for answers.

Often, puzzles only reward you with more puzzles, sometimes harder, and sometimes easier. The difficulty in this game seems to be spontaneous, which is a mystery on its own. A lot of rooms have you walking for what seems like an eternity before giving you a clue, forcing you to glide back to the beginning and solve it.

I played through this with a walkthrough open in another tab because I found myself getting frustrated with certain puzzles. Most of them, however, are pretty straightforward. Besides the puzzles, this game is a walking simulator with some interesting environments.

Graphics: Nothing special. It runs well and is ocassionally pretty to look at, but is mostly pretty bland.

Level Design: The environments are neat but I felt like it could've been designed better and been more polished. I've played loads of other trippy indie games such as this, and this one really felt like it was lacking in level design creativity. Most of the environments are pretty blocky and boring, and every room is a different shade of one color.

Story: As is common with these strange indie games, the story isn't too important. From what I gathered, you're exploring old ruins and contraptions and you're reactivating them, bringing life back to these environments. That's the jist, it's nothing special.

Overall, I enjoyed the experience, and the length was just about right. If it had gone on longer I feel like I would've gotten sick of it. There's lots of secrets to keep you busy if you're an achievment hunter, but the gameplay wasn't interesting enough for me to find all of the secrets. Get it on a sale if you're into these kinds of games. 6/10
Cool puzzles, but you may get lost easily because the game lacks information and directions sometimes
A pretty simple game with nice puzzles. Simple puzzles. Nothing too complicated so it is suitable to play to de-stress. Would be nicer with a storyline though...
Very bizzare and intriguing game. If you liked Antichamber, you'll be into this too. I played this game about 2 years ago and still think about it.
I'm not sure what was going on, and gave me a pretty good headache. If you get headaches easily would not reccomend this.

It's a really beautiful game. It's art, minimalist, atmospheric art. A few of the puzzles can be nearly impossible to figure out without the use of a guide, but fortunately there are some great guides in the community. There isn't much replay value after the game is done, but I put in a lot of hours before completing it.

In any case, I definitely recommend it.

9/10

Like abstract Myst-likes? Like puzzle games? Like first-person walking simulators? If any of these apply to you, get this game when it's on sale. Kairo is a gem of a game that is great for those who love the sense of isolation, mystic settings, and eerie music.

Kairo is a slow-paced puzzle game in a similar vein to Myst, if Myst didn't have all the annoying pixel-hunting and weren't a point and click game. Its atmosphere is surreal, strange, and overwhelmingly lonesome. That's the big word I think I'd use to describe this game - lonesome, and that lonesomeness becomes more and more eerie the further you go into the game. You are the only living thing in Kairo - everything else is a hollow, dead fascimile, with archetecture eerily reminiscent of human construction and yet alien enough you might think you woke up in R'lyeh. The world of Kairo is a small world that feels massive, alien, and completely dead... and I love it to pieces and back.\n\nWandering through the surreal and beautifully eerie world of Kairo is very relaxing, the puzzles are very intuitive and can easily be solved with a little thought, and the simple design really makes it feel like you're stranded. And yet, solving the puzzles is so satisfying, satisfying in that I'm a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ed genius!" sort of way. The range of feelings you get from Kairo goes from triumph
hoursPlayed: paranoia
voteText: and hopelessness - and what is art if not something that makes you feel deeply? Anyone who claims video games aren't art has never played this
helpfulPercent: and that's a damn shame. Did I mention that the music and the game's design is just so surrealistically gorgeous?\n\nSeriously
votesHelpful: BUY THIS GAME. It's maybe $5 for a wonderful little piece of surrealistic artwork that recaptures the eerie loneliness and thirst for adventure that Myst did so many years ago in 1992. Kairo is a gem of an indie puzzle game

Kairo is nothing like Antichamber, and if you're expecting it to be then you're about to be sorely disappointed. This is not to say that I didn't like Kairo, as you can presumably tell from the fact that this review is a recommendation. reviewText:
This is a game I desperately wanted to like.  At first I did, it was surreal and interesting to explore and wander.  Then the puzzles came.  Dear god, the puzzles.  Everything outside of the game made it seem as though the puzzles would be short and scarce throughout the game...  That is a lie!  The puzzles make about as much sense as something from a point-and-click adventure game.  The puzzle is nearly always figuring out the mechanics of the puzzle, rather than what to do, which is horribly frustrating.  I never thought it possible to rage quit a first person exploration game.  Then I did the impossible, and did just that.

The enviroments themselves are nice, usually only using one or two colors per room.  The only problem I really have with the world is that it's incredibly inconsistant.  The world is obviously not made to feel like it has rules, which I normally wouldn't have a problem with.  It's just some sort of strange, lawless purgatory type setting, right?  I wish.  It's actually supposed to be an alien planet.  It just doesn't work at all.

TL;DR:  I desperately wanted to like this game a lot, but it left a lot to be desired with terrible puzzles EVERYWHERE and and inconsistant world.

4/10  Don't buy this game.  Just don't.

Vast , simple and yet rich in atmosphere, with pure relaxing gameplay.\nSimilar to journey in feel but has the essence of many great games.\nIncredible value and an example why steam is essential to any gamer.

You can play this with just the mouse. Move mouse to look, left click to walk and right click to jump. Your other hand...while watching the beautiful sexy scenery...... yknow... masturbate. /OverdoneJoke
Very gentle puzzler with some ambiguity of context, but really you'd have to like this kind of game to want to play it; it doesn't feel to me like it offers anything for the passerby.

Kairo is certainly an odd game. Definitily not for everyone. However, if you are a fan of explorative puzzle games, I highly recommend it. It almost reminds me of the Myst series, in the sense that you are never given proper direction in how to solve the game, but each area is designed to keep the player interested and almost needing to solve the area. I will say that the feeling I get whenever I solve one of the puzzles is immensly satisfying. It brings me back to the roots of what made me love puzzle games to start with. Not to mention that the world you are given to explore is absolutly gorgeous.
Bare world and majoraly unplayable.

I very much enjoyed this game.  There is not enough like this out there.  The game felt very personal, and there was something about the world that kept you exploring.  The atmosphere was wonderful, and it transports you away to this strange and bizarre world.  The conclusion of the game kept me thinking for a while as to the meaning of the game, and I came to a few conclusions.  That is what makes this a good game, it can be interpreted in many different ways.  I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys more atmospheric games with mild puzzle solving elements.  Some of the puzzles are very difficult, there is still one that I cannot solve.  The most difficult puzzles are the ones that really demand you to pay attention to your environment.

reviewText: This game is a giant mystery. I had no idea what was going on half of the time, or why they made certain areas the way they did. I think it's a good game, with a nice soundtrack and smooth controls, and it's definitely something to check out.

A strange, short, intriguing little game. I'd say I enjoyed it for the most part.

Gameplay: The puzzles are usually pretty decent and not too difficult to figure out. However, there are times when it takes too much trial and error and guesswork rather than intuition and observation. I played through this with a walkthrough open in another tab because I found myself getting frustrated with certain puzzles. Most of them, however, are pretty straightforward. Besides the puzzles, this game is a walking simulator with some interesting environments.

Graphics: Nothing special. It runs well and is ocassionally pretty to look at, but is mostly pretty bland.

Level Design: The environments are neat but I felt like it could've been designed better and been more polished. I've played loads of other trippy indie games such as this, and this one really felt like it was lacking in level design creativity. Most of the environments are pretty blocky and boring, and every room is a different shade of one color.

Story: As is common with these strange indie games, the story isn't too important. From what I gathered, you're exploring old ruins and contraptions and you're reactivating them, bringing life back to these environments. That's the jist, it's nothing special.

Overall, I enjoyed the experience, and the length was just about right. If it had gone on longer I feel like I would've gotten sick of it. There's lots of secrets to keep you busy if you're an achievment hunter, but the gameplay wasn't interesting enough for me to find all of the secrets. Get it on a sale if you're into these kinds of games. 6/10

reviewText:
I liked it.

The game has a nice surreal ambiance and sorta eerie music. You walk through majestic and mysterious places solving puzzles, some simple, some that might need a google search. Only once did I actually need a google search to help me solve a puzzle (turns out i was right about how to solve it, was just applying it incorrectly). Solving every secret and puzzle, especially those not required to beat the game, will definitely take an internet search to finish.

Gameplay only requires moving and the rare jump and nothing else. There are no other requirements, all puzzles are solved with simply walking, and buttons/interactive objects are used simply by walking up to/on them. The simplicity of both gameplay and the story telling is not for everyone, but I personally loved the game.

I would recommend this game for people who enjoying exploring and doing unrequired things in games and also enjoy puzzles and deep thinking. If you prefer very linear and directed gameplay or don't enjoy going outside of the main story to explore, you probably will dislike the game.

As some of the reviewers say, Kairo is... odd. It feels a bit like exploring the inside of someone's mind.\n\nI found it fascinating.

Overall, a very interesting game with a perplexing, dream-like setting and nice mid-level puzzles.  But there is no concrete story or true gameplay beyond the puzzle solving, so if that turns you off, this title is not for you.

In the current gaming setting of triple A titles with increasingly beautiful and realistic graphics, I was a bit off-put by the blocky, grainy architecture of the game.  At first.  Then I realized how brilliantly atmospheric it was.  Lonely and creepy, Kairo is very reminiscent of the first Myst game: a solo protagonist working their way through a mysterious world, piecing the story together as you go, never quite sure if you've gotten it right.

If you're a completionist, prepare for a lot of backtracking, as some things are only activated after you get all the way through an area.  If you're not, don't worry about missing out on anything more than full exploration of the environment.  The final secret is funny but not story-related.

reviewText: Never before have I felt so small or so lonely.

I haven't seen much about these points yet, I'm just adding to others' reviews.

This one's about solving some puzzles  in a hyper dimensional alien space to turn some machines on after the apocalypse.
Graphical design is going for minimalistic abstract representation of stone buildings, so I'm certain there's less than 100 textures in the entire game. Explorable empty space is used to show importance of an object in the room, and over-saturated lighting is used almost randomly, but consistently through a room.
Sound design follows graphical design, and follows a theme of emptiness and alienation in an abstract world.
The physics and control are poor, but only because they are unnecessary for the gameplay.
Gameplay itself is puzzle solving in insolation, but the main story puzzles are simple. It's a small game that takes time to explore for 100% completion. The 100% content beyond the main story puzzles just involves finding hidden things and backtracking after hitting an obvious switch to find a matching shape somewhere.

After breaking it down like that, I think it'd make for a really nice modern art machinima.
As far as being a game, it can be depressing for a few reasons. That's why I recommend it.
WTF!?
Good puzzles.  Some are a bit abstract and take a bit more of a think to figure out but are still solvable.  Also the art direction is great

Kairo is a slightly flawed gem of a first-person walking and exploration game. It requires a bit of investment to stay interested in the beginning, but if you're into discovery and piecing together parts of a mystery, it eventually rewards that patience.

In the beginning, you appear in Kairo with no explanation of who you are, where you are, what its or your purpose is, and no apparent indication of what you should do next, other than possibly head towards the one visible structure in the distance. Hints as to possible answers to all of those questions gradually unfold as you proceed through the three main levels of the game. Ultimately, the game never concretely answers any of those questions, but gives you enough (especially if you're determined to hunt down and unlock all of its sometimes-obscure riddles) to put together your guess, your interpretation of what you've just been through. For some this may be frustrating, not to know the absolute official canon truth of the matter, but I see it as one of the game's strengths in creating a real sense of mystery. This is not your typical berk-without-a-past-uncovers-his-past story—however much you discover, you remain without a past.

The game suffers from some minor flaws in execution—the occasional video clipping problem in tight spaces, oddly getting stuck on stairs and needing to jump to continue, footstep sounds that are weirdly unsynchronized to your movement—that reflect a slight lack of polish. For me, these minor issues pale in comparison to what the game achieves artistically. It manages to create, through the grand scale of its environments, the use of colour, and its moody, atmospheric soundtrack, a feeling of being very small and alone in an intimidating, unknown world which is somehow broken and needs fixing. The puzzles involved in the fixing range from trivial to frustratingly obscure, but for the impatient there are guides and walkthroughs, and for the determined, there's a great sense of accomplishment in untangling the secret.
Great game.Nice & relaxing. Take your time and enjoy the visuals. I want a sequel!

A friend of mine showed me this game a while back, he bought it for me and I'm glad he did. I really enjoyed the puzzles and how it looked, especially the grain filter, that gave it a really interesting feel. The game is not horror at all, though it can be a bit spooky due to the environment and the sounds, but thats what I loved about it. The game also had a Myst feel to it, if anyone reading this actually knows what that game is. Sure this game may seem strange at first, but give it a try, you might actually like it! Definitely worth the price.

Kairo is as simple as it gets. It is an artsy, abstract and super minimalist walking simulator. And, as such, I think it excel, as it is always throwing at you new kind of imagery, puzzle and scenery. At no point I found Kairo to be lazy, reusing too often room design. I recommend using a guide though. Due to the minimalistic approch of the game, some puzzle are very cryptic.\n\nIf the idea of walking through monochrome rooms of block, sphere and triangle while engulfing deeply into your own though and emotion, you will like this game. My advice is to surrender yourself to Kairo and let every bit of creativity sink in without looking for a finite explanation of what is happening around you.
